Editor's choice paper Significant effect of In doping on Ni/C catalyst for hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to ethanol: Synergistic effect of InNi3 alloy, surface oxygen, and defect sites Jiang Gong Methodology Validation Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Hanqing Zhang Writing – review & editing Validation Visualization Weihan Shu Writing – review & editing Validation Fengling Zheng Writing – review & editing Siqian Qin Writing – review & editing Xue Wang Writing – review & editing Chuancai Zhang Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Project administration ⁎ Haodong Xue Writing – review & editing Bin Dai Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shihezi University, Shihezi 832003, PR China Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shihezi University Shihezi 832003 PR China Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shihezi University, Shihezi 832003, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The Ni-In/C catalyst, prepared using a one-pot method, demonstrates superior catalytic performance compared to the Ni/C catalyst in the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to ethanol (EtOH). The introduction of doping results in the formation of defect sites and InNi3 alloy, enhancing both the adsorption of DMO and the activation of H2. Additionally, the presence of -OH groups (acting as Bronsted acid sites) on the carbon surface activates C-O, thereby effectively promoting the deep hydrogenation of intermediate products to produce EtOH. The catalyst exhibits remarkable industrial potential by achieving high ethanol yield through a straightforward preparation method, while maintaining low Ni content. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dimethyl oxalate Ethanol Hydrogenation InNi3 alloy Surface oxygen Defects Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethanol (EtOH) is an important chemical widely used in medical disinfectants, fuel cells, and ethanol gasoline [1,2]. Traditionally, ethanol is produced through biological fermentation and ethylene hydration [3,4], However, these processes are constrained by oil scarcity and expensive biomass production [5]. Alternatively, the synthesis of ethanol from syngas has garnered considerable attention due to its wide availability and low cost, as syngas can be obtained from coal, natural gas, or factory waste gas [6–8]. In particular, the industrialization of glycol production from syngas via dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation has been realized in China. Nevertheless, there are still some technical challenges, and the DMO hydrogenation catalyst needs further improvement. Currently, copper-based catalysts have been considered suitable for the hydrogenation of esters, widely employed in the DMO hydrogenation to EtOH [9–12]. The synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu° facilitates the selective adsorption of C=O on Cu+ and dissociation of H2 on Cu0, promoting the hydrogenation of intermediates (MG, EG) to ethanol. However, copper-based catalysts produce C3-C4 alcohols and other by-products, resulting in low EtOH selectivity [9], Additionally, Cu-based catalysts are prone to sintering and agglomeration at high temperatures, leading to poor stability, which limits their application [13–16]. To address these disadvantages, many domestic and foreign scholars have researched and developed non-Cu-based catalysts, such as Fe/mesC [17] and Pd-In2O3/ZrO2 [18] catalysts, which exhibit excellent catalytic activity for ethanol production but with high by-product yields. Given its excellent hydrogen dissociation performance and lower cost, we utilized transition metal Ni as the active component for DMO hydrogenation to EtOH. Ni has been successfully used in selective hydrogenation reactions of CO2 [19,20] and furfural (FF) [21,22]. As DMO hydrogenation involves the same hydrogenation of C=O as CO2 and FF hydrogenation, Ni is a suitable choice for the DMO hydrogenation process. Various Ni catalysts for DMO hydrogenation have been reported [23–25]. For instance, a FeNi3-FeOX/Ni foam catalyst prepared using nickel foam achieved a 98 % ethanol yield and stable operation for 700 h [24].The high Ni content and complex preparation method of this catalyst, however, impose limitations on its application. Therefore, the development of a highly active ethanol catalyst with low Ni content and a simplified preparation method is crucial for industrial implementation. Studies have shown that indium oxide is an efficient catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation [26–31]. Indium oxide provides more oxygen vacancies, promoting CO2 activation, and has been widely utilized by scholars for CO2 hydrogenation to produce downstream products. Based on this concept, indium is chosen as an additive for DMO hydrogenation to produce EtOH. EtOH is a product of deep hydrogenation of DMO, and the adsorption activation of intermediate products (EG, MG) is crucial to improve the yield of EtOH, which involves the adsorption activation of C-O. Previous research has indicated that the hydroxyl groups on the carbon carrier's surface can act as Bronsted acid sites, promoting the adsorption and activation of C-O on the catalyst [32–34]. This, in turn, facilitates further hydrodehydroxylation of intermediate products to produce ethanol. Thus, it is hypothesized that the carbon-supported Ni-In catalyst (N-In/C) possesses excellent catalytic activity and stability for DMO hydrogenation to EtOH. A carbon-supported Ni-In/C catalyst (Ni-In/C) was prepared using glucose as the carbon source through a straightforward one-pot method. The impact of the molar ratio of Ni/In and carbonization temperature on catalytic activity was investigated. The catalyst was prepared using a straightforward method, resulting in exceptional EtOH yield despite low Ni content. Moreover, it exhibited remarkable stability and displayed significant potential for industrial applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Dimethyl oxalate (C4H6O4), nickel tetrahydrate acetate (Ni(CH3COO)2∙4H2O), indium nitrate hydrate (In(NO3)3∙XH2O), glucose (C6H12O6), urea (CH4N2O), ethanol (C2H6O), and methanol (C4H6O4) were used to conduct the experiments. 2.2 Ni-In/C preparation of catalyst The catalyst was prepared using a one-pot method as follows: A certain amount of glucose, urea, nickel acetate tetrahydrate, and indium nitrate hydrate were weighed and dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water. The mixture was then subjected to ultrasonic mixing for 0.5 h to form a homogenous solution. Next, the solution was transferred to a polytetrafluoroethylene-lined autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 12 h. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, the solid products were collected by centrifugation. The collected solids were washed three times with ethanol and deionized water, then dried at 80 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the dried solid product was carbonized in a nitrogen environment at 600 °C for 2 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min). Finally, the carbonized sample was subjected to the reduction process in a mixture of H2 and N2 (molar fraction of H2: 5 %) at 410 °C for 4 h to obtain the catalyst product labeled as wNix-Iny/C-T (where w represents the mass ratio of Ni to C, x:y represents the molar ratio of Ni to In, and T represents the carbonization temperature). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalyst's structure and crystallinity were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) on a Rigaku Ultra IV diffractometer. Copper Kα radiation (γ = 0.152) at 40 KV and 40 mA was used for the analysis in the range of 10–90°, with a scan rate of 8° min−1. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were recorded using the JEM2100PLUS high-resolution transmission electron microscope. Prior to measurement, the sample was evenly dispersed in an ethanol solvent and placed on a copper web. The specific surface area (SBET), pore size distribution, and pore volume of the catalyst were determined using the ASAP2020 automatic Micropore and chemisorption instrument. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the sample was measured at −196 °C. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed on the Nicolet iS50 spectrometer. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on the Quantachrome AMI-90 chemisorbent apparatus, and the hydrogen consumption was determined by a TCD detector. 2.4 Evaluation of DMO hydrogenation The DMO hydrogenation experiment was conducted using a fixed bed reactor with dimensions of 300 mm in length, 8 mm in inner diameter, and 16 mm in outer diameter. A total of 0.28 g of catalyst was loaded into the stainless-steel fixed bed reactor with an 8 mm inner diameter. The evaluation of the catalyst's DMO hydrogenation performance was carried out using the continuous flow method. During the reaction, the reactant, a 15 wt.% DMO methanol solution, was pumped into the reactor using a high-pressure pump. The reactant was then mixed with hydrogen at a flow rate of 51 ml/min for the reaction. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was tested at a (Weight Hourly Space Velocity of DMO(WHSVDMO) of 0.3 h−1, a reaction temperature of 290 °C, and a pressure of 2.5 MPa. The reaction products were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC) technology on a GC-9790PLUS instrument by Foley Instrument. A capillary column with dimensions of 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 μm was used, and the analysis was performed using a flame ionization detector (FID). The turnover frequency (TOF) value is calculated when the DMO conversion rate is below 20 %, by maintaining a high DMO liquid-hour airspeed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of the 0.25Ni/C-600, 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600, and wNi3-In1/C-600 catalysts are shown in Figs. 1 and S1. The 0.25Ni/C-600 catalyst exhibits diffraction peaks of metal Ni (PDF#04–0850) and graphite C (PDF#50–0926), while the content of In in the catalysts varies. Different Ni/In molar ratios form different Ni-In intermetallic compounds (Ni-In IMC). Specifically, when the Ni/In molar ratio is 1 and 2, InNi-IMC (PDF#07–0178) and In3Ni2-IMC (PDF#07–0298) are primarily formed, respectively. However, InNi3C0.5 (PDF#28–0468) is primarily formed when the molar ratio of Ni/In continues to increase, and its strength gradually decreases with a further increase in the Ni/In molar ratio, indicating a significant effect of the Ni/In molar ratio on the formation of InNi3C0.5. Notably, a diffraction peak characterizing metal Ni is observed in the profile when the Ni/In molar ratio is 5. This can be potentially attributed to the low content of In in the material. The XRD pattern of the wNi3-In1/C-600 catalyst (Fig. S1) indicates that different Ni/C mass ratios do not affect the crystalline phase of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the XRD pattern of the 0.25Ni3-In1/C-T catalyst (Fig. S5) also shows the same properties. These characterization results demonstrate that the crystalline phase of the catalyst is primarily influenced by the molar ratio of Ni/In. Analysis of Fig. 2 reveals that the 0.25Ni/C-600 and 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600 catalysts exhibit typical type IV isotherms and B-type hysteresis rings. This indicates that the catalysts possess abundant mesopores, which are primarily strip pores. The average pore diameter of the catalysts is in the range of 6–7 nm. The results are consistent with the results obtained by analyzing the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (Table S1). Additionally, the specific surface area (SBET), total pore volume (PV), and pore size (Dpore) of 0.25Ni/C-600 are 164 m2g−1, 0.236 m3g−1, and 18.794 nm, respectively. In comparison, 0.25Ni3-In1/C-600 is characterized by lower values (109 m2g−1, 0.174 m3g−1, and 13.43 nm, respectively) (Table 1 ). The results could be attributed to the introduction of In and partial pore plugging. The morphology, structure, and dispersion of the active components in the catalyst were analyzed using the TEM technique. Analysis of the TEM images (Fig. S2) reveals that all the catalysts form a flake-stacked spherical structure. The prominence of this morphology increased with an increase in the molar ratio of Ni/In. The catalysts primarily consist of bar pores, and the results agree well with the results obtained by analyzing the BET profiles. The distribution diagram of catalyst particle size in Fig. 3 (a–f) reveals that the average particle size of the catalyst is increased by doping In. This can be potentially attributed to the formation of Ni-In IMC under conditions of In doping. However, the particle size first decreases and then increases with an increase in the Ni/In molar ratio (that is, the content of In decreases). The results indicate that an appropriate In content promotes the dispersion of active components, resulting in the exposure of a large number of active sites and the improvement of catalyst activity. High-resolution TEM images reveal the presence of uniformly dispersed InNi3C0.5 nanoparticles (size: approximately 8 nm; Fig. 3(k)). The lattice fringes presented a plane spacing of 0.218 nm, and this corresponded to the InNi3C0.5(111) plane (Fig. 3(l)). The surface scanning of the energy spectrum (TEM-Mapping) revealed that C, Ni, and In were evenly distributed in a part of the TEM image (Fig. 3 (g–j)), and the distribution of Ni and In elements was comparable. This further verified the formation of InNi3C0.5. Raman spectrograms were analyzed to study the formation of carbon defect sites in the 0.25Ni/C-600 and 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600 catalysts (Fig. 4 ). In all catalysts, two characteristic peaks were observed at approximately 1343 cm−1 (D band; corresponding to the A1g vibration mode characterizing the sp3 defective carbon systems) and 1575 cm−1 (G band; E2g vibration mode characterizing sp2 graphitic carbon systems). The D to G band intensity ratio (ID/IG) can represent the relative content of the defect sites in the catalyst. The results indicate that the presence of In enhances the formation of defect sites in the catalyst, with 0.25Ni3-In1/C-600 exhibiting the presence of the maximum number of defect sites. These defect sites promote the adsorption of C=O on the catalyst [32], thereby enhancing the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The chemical states of C, Ni, In, and O in the 0.25Ni/C-600 and 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600 catalysts were characterized using the XPS technique. Analysis of Fig. 5 reveals the presence of C, Ni, In, and O. Fig. 6 reveals that the binding energies of Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/2 are 852.7 and 870.1 eV, respectively, and these peaks correspond to Ni0 in 0.25Ni/C-600 [35], respectively. However, the peak corresponding to Ni0 in 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600 shifts towards lower binding energy regions. The peaks corresponding to In3d3/2 and In3d5/2 appear at 444.2 and 451.6 eV, respectively, and these peaks correspond to In0 in 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600. The binding energy of this system is higher than the binding energy of In (444.0 eV and 451.4 eV, respectively) [36], suggesting charge transfer between Ni and In. This reflects the fact that the electronegativity of Ni (1.91 eV) is higher than that of In (1.78 eV). The results indicate a strong interaction between Ni and In. Additionally, analysis of Fig. 7 reveals that the peaks corresponding to O1s in 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600 shift toward lower binding energy regions (compared to the peaks corresponding to 0.25Ni/C-600), indicating that the presence of In promotes metal-carrier interaction, which eventually results in enhanced catalytic activity. Fig. 7 presents the O1s spectral profile. This profile can be divided into three parts: C=O bond (531.1 eV), C-O bond (532.5 eV), and adsorbed water (533.6 eV) [32,37]. The C-O content in different systems has been presented: 5.00 % (Ni1-In1/C) > 4.61 % (Ni2-In1/C) > 3.79 % (Ni3-In1/C) > 2.96 % (Ni4-In1/C) > 2.80 % (Ni5-In1/C) > 1.38 % (Ni/C). The results reveal that indium doping increases the C-O bond content of the catalyst hydroxyl group. This is also validated by analyzing the C1s electron energy spectral profile (Fig. S3). The C/O content ratio determined by analyzing the full spectral profile further verifies this finding (Fig. 5). These results demonstrate that the -OH groups on the catalyst surface can act as Bronsted acids [32–34], promoting the activation of C-O and resulting in improved catalyst performance. Analysis of the FT-IR spectral profile presented in Fig. 8 confirms the presence of oxygen-containing groups [38,39] in the catalysts. The peak at 3416 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the O-H group, while the peak at 1637 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of the C=O unit in the aldehyde group. The C-C and C-O stretching vibrations appear at 1384 and 1131 cm−1, respectively. Additionally, the stretching vibration of the C=C units in the aromatic group appears at 1612 cm−1. This can potentially explain the aromatization of glucose during the hydrothermal process [40]. The effect of In doping on the process of catalyst reduction was investigated by analyzing the H2-TPR curves (Fig. 9 ). The peak corresponding to 0.25Ni/C-600 in the TPR curve, centered at 670 °C, can be attributed to the reduction of NiO [41]. It has been observed that In doping reduces the reduction temperature of NiO, and the reduction temperature is in the range of 200–600 °C. This indicates an interaction between Ni and In, and similar results were obtained using the XPS technique. The shift of the reduction peak also indicates that In doping enhances the catalyst's ability to activate H2, resulting in improved deep hydrogenation capability and increased activity for DMO hydrogenation. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalyst As seen from Table 2 , the DMO conversion and EtOH selectivity of 0.25Ni/C-600 are significantly lower than those of 0.25Nix-Iny/C-600, indicating a synergistic effect of Ni and In on the hydrogenation of DMO to ethanol. This effect could be attributed to the formation of InNi3C0.5, the reduction of metal particles, and the enhancement of metal dispersion. These results were obtained using the XRD, XPS, and TEM techniques. Furthermore, the Ni/In molar ratio significantly influences the activity of the catalyst. As the Ni/In molar ratio increases from 1 to 3, the yield of ethanol increases from 68 to 82 %. However, the ethanol yield decreases with a further increase in the Ni/In molar ratio. These results align with the changes observed in the strength of the InNi3C0.5 alloy based on XRD analysis. The findings suggest that the indium content affects the formation of the InNi3C0.5 alloy. InNi3 within InNi3C0.5 plays a crucial role in the adsorption and activation of C=O in DMO on the catalyst [25], and the increase in the number of active sites is conducive to the hydrogenation of DMO to ethanol. Moreover, the content of the defect sites in the catalyst is directly proportional to the yield of ethanol, indicating that the formation of the defect site has a significant effect on the activity of the catalyst. The results reveal that the formation of the defect site is conducive to the adsorption of C=O on the catalyst [32], and this improves the efficiency of the DMO hydrogenation process, which results in the production of ethanol. In addition, the -OH groups on the catalyst surface can act as the Bronsted acidic sites to promote the adsorption and activation of C-OC-O on the catalyst [32–34]. However, the content of -OH is the highest when Ni/In is 1. It has been observed that the optimal catalytic activity is not recorded under these conditions. This can be potentially attributed to the lack of InNi3C0.5 formation and defect sites, resulting in insufficient activation of C=O on the catalyst. The relationship between turnover frequency (TOF) and different Ni/In molar ratio at high liquid space velocity was concurrently measured, while also investigating the molar ratio on the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. The results demonstrate that the optimal TOF value can be attained with a Ni/In molar ratio of 3. It is evident from Table 3 that the w(Ni/C mass ratio) also has a significant impact on the EtOH product yield. The results obtained using the XRD technique (Fig. S1) reveal that the strength of the formed InNi3C0.5 alloy gradually increases with an increase in w. Therefore, it is speculated that the lower activity observed at w = 0.15 can be potentially attributed to the low InNi3C0.5 alloy content (in other words, the low number of active sites). The ethanol yield at w = 0.35 is lower than that at w = 0.25. This can be potentially explained by the fact that an excess of Ni results in the agglomeration of the active components, which eventually results in a reduction in the number of exposed active sites and reduced catalytic activity. The results are validated by the results obtained using the TEM technique (Fig. 10 ), indicating that the optimal Ni/C mass ratio is 0.25. Analysis of Table 4 reveals that the ethanol yield initially increases and then decreases as the carbonization temperature increases from 500 to 800 °C. The yield of ethylene glycol exhibits the opposite trend under the same conditions. The ethylene glycol yield is as high as 33.63 % when the carbonization temperature is 800 °C. This indicates that the carbonization temperature significantly influences the process of DMO hydrogenation. In order to investigate the reasons, we initially conducted XRD analysis on catalysts prepared at various carbonization temperatures. As depicted in Fig. S5, the strength of the gradually formed InNi3C0.5 alloy increased with rising carbonization temperature Hence, we hypothesized that the low performance 500 °C was attributed to a reduced content of InNi3C0.5 alloy. However, as the carbonization temperature further increased, the catalyst's activity exhibited an initial increase followed by a subsequent decrease, indicating that DMO hydrogenation to EtOH is influenced not only by the formation of InNi3C0.5 alloy. This phenomenon can be attributed to the effect of carbonization temperature on the content of -OH in the catalyst. Fig. 11 reveals that the content of -OH in the catalyst gradually decreases with an increase in the carbonization temperature. This is also confirmed by the results obtained by analyzing the C1s spectral profile (Fig. S4). The -OH groups act as Bronsted acid sites that promote the adsorption and activation of C-O [32–34], which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of DMO and its corresponding intermediates (MA, EG). This promotes the process of the formation of ethanol. However, at a carbonization temperature of 800 °C, the -OH content is too low to effectively adsorb and activate C-O in ethylene glycol, forming a large amount of ethylene glycol. The catalytic performance is poorer than that of the 0.25Ni3-In1/C-600 catalyst even though the -OH content is the highest at the carbonization temperature of 500 °C. This can be potentially attributed to the fact that the carbonization temperature affects the formation of catalyst defect sites. Raman spectral profiles (Fig. 12 ) were analyzed at different carbonization temperatures, and the results reveal that the content of defect sites increases with an increase in the carbonization temperature. The number of defect sites in the catalysts is too low to effectively adsorb and activate C=O when the carbonization temperature is 500 °C [32]. This hinders the deep hydrogenation of DMO, resulting in a low ethanol yield. Furthermore, the strength of the D and G bands decreases with the increase in carbonization temperature, and this can be potentially attributed to the absence of carbon structure during high-temperature carbonization [42]. It can be inferred that the optimal carbonization temperature is 600 °C. After a series of condition optimizations, the catalyst stability evaluation was conducted under the optimal reaction conditions. As depicted in Fig. 13 , the catalytic performance remained unaltered for 240 h, indicating excellent catalytic stability of the Ni-In/C catalyst. Furthermore, employing a straightforward preparation method allows achieving higher ethanol yield with reduced nickel content compared to previous works (Table S2). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a Ni-In/C catalyst was successfully prepared using a one-pot method and glucose as the carbon source. The Ni/In molar ratios had significant effects on the nature and process of the formation of crystal phases and the content of defect sites, InNi3C0.5 was formed at an Ni/In molar ratio of 3, resulting in the generation of a large number of defect sites, which facilitated the adsorption of DMO and promoted the formation of intermediate products (mainly EG and MG). The catalyst exhibited excellent metal dispersion properties under these conditions. Furthermore, the presence of In promoted Ni-In interaction and metal–carrier interaction. This contributed to the improvement in catalytic activity. The carbonization temperature primarily affected the defect sites and the content of -OH on the surface of the carbon supports. The -OH units functioned as Bronsted acid sites, promoting the adsorption of C-O, which eventually facilitated the continued hydrogenation of intermediate products. This resulted in the production of EtOH and improved the deep hydrogenation capability of the system, which resulted in the formation of EtOH from DMO. The synergistic effects of InNi3C0.5 alloy, defect sites and -OH group promote the deep hydrogenation of DMO to produce EtOH. coredata.dc:description: The Ni-In/C catalyst, prepared using a one-pot method, demonstrates superior catalytic performance compared to the Ni/C catalyst in the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to ethanol (EtOH). The introduction of doping results in the formation of defect sites and InNi3 alloy, enhancing both the adsorption of DMO and the activation of H2. Additionally, the presence of -OH groups (acting as Bronsted acid sites) on the carbon surface activates C-O, thereby effectively promoting the deep hydrogenation of intermediate products to produce EtOH. The catalyst exhibits remarkable industrial potential by achieving high ethanol yield through a straightforward preparation method, while maintaining low Ni content.
coredata.dc:title: Significant effect of In doping on Ni/C catalyst for hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to ethanol: Synergistic effect of InNi3 alloy, surface oxygen, and defect sites
